Om inte annat beordras stannar umbraskropparna i detta område och försvarar sig vid behov. Om karaktärerna är på gravplatsen tillräckligt länge kan de bevittna hur umber hulks hugger ut nya områden av fängelsehålan i den tomma delen av kartan.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Om en mekanisk guide spenderar 1 laddning i det här området får umber hulks att antingen återvända hit för att vila om de är någon annanstans, eller att gå till graven för att börja arbeta och öppna eller stänga stenplattan i enlighet med detta.

entries.name: 3. Entrance to the Tomb

entries: Denna breda tunnel håller för närvarande på att formas till gravens genomarbetade ingång. Detta är en aktiv plats med ett antal hantverkare som arbetar i lyktljus för att gipsa väggarna och måla dem med ljusa, färgglada väggmålningar. Andra hantverkare håller på att täcka golvet med en genomarbetad mosaik med en distinkt slingrande väg av röda plattor, av vilka några korsar en rad öppna gropar.

Området är bullrigt med ljudet av hammarslagning och stenhuggning som kommer från väster (område 8 och 10). Om umbrahultarna gräver kan ett mullrande också höras i öster. Men även över allt detta kan karaktärerna höra en rytmisk sång som kommer från söder (som bärs från kapellet i {@area area 14|093|x} genom magin från Phenex ceremoni).

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Tolv neutrala {@creature Tiefling Muralist|IMR|tiefling muralists} arbetar här och blandar ständigt nya pigment som ska appliceras på gipsväggarna. En muralist använder {@creature cultist} statblocket med följande ändringar:

items: Den känner till {@spell thaumaturgy} kantrip.
Den är motståndskraftig mot brandskador.
Den har {@sense darkvision} upp till en räckvidd på 60 fot.
Det talar Common och Infernal.

entries: En lyckad DC 14 Wisdom ({@skill Perception})-kontroll som görs av en karaktär som tittar på pigmenten som förbereds identifierar ingredienserna som inkluderar omöjligt ljusrött blod. Om de blir tillfrågade talar muralisterna om att de arbetar i graven i tjänande av dess konst, som överskrider alla andra bekymmer. De hänvisar karaktärerna antingen till {@creature Moghadam|IMR} eller vidare till Phenex som svar på alla andra frågor.

entries.name: Murals
entries: Om väggmålningarna undersöks, läs följande (från originalet {@adventure Tomb of Horrors|TftYP}):

De målade scenerna visar fält med betande kossor, en skogsdunge med flera vargar i bakgrunden, slavar (människor, orcher, alver och en märklig blandning av människor och djur: gris-människa, apa-människa och hund-människa) som utför olika uppgifter. Vissa av freskerna visar rummen i någon byggnad: ett bibliotek fyllt med många böcker och skriftrullar, en tortyrkammare, en trollkarls arbetsrum. Stolar, fönster, lådor, balar, dörrar, kistor, fåglar, fladdermöss, spindlar och allt möjligt visas på väggarna.

entries.name: Looking South
entries: Muralisternas lykta lyser upp den norra halvan av detta område. Detaljerna i {@area area 6|072|x} syns endast när karaktärer med {@sense darkvision} eller en ljuskälla rör sig tillräckligt nära slutet av hallen.

entries.name: Open Pits
entries: På flera ställen korsar den slingrande mosaikvägen en rad öppna gropar som ännu inte är täckta och dolda. De fyra första groparna är vardera tre meter djupa och tomma utom för sopor.

Den grop som leder till {@area area 7|076|x} är 30 fot djup och innehåller en stege. Karaktärer som bevakar detta område tillräckligt länge ser hur muralisterna regelbundet klättrar ner i denna grop och senare återvänder med flaskor med ljusrött blod (som hämtas från Nolzur i {@area area 7|076|x}) för att blandas till nya pigment.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Om en mekanisk guide spenderar 1 laddning i det här området får en av muralisterna att gå ner i den sydligaste gropen för att hämta mer blod från Nolzur (hålls i {@area area 7|076|x}). Om Nolzur har räddats rapporterar muralisterna detta till {@creature Moghadam|IMR}, som samlar tillgängliga arbetare för att jaga efter den försvunna tjuven.

entries.name: 4. Side Entrance
entries: Denna del av väggen har ännu inte putsats eller målats över och lämnar en öppen dörröppning som leder västerut. Gropen före dörröppningen genomkorsas av en rad träplankor.

entries.name: 5. Control Room

entries: Genom en stenvalv kan man se flera grupper av paneler och instrument längs väggarna. De sprakar av gnistor av eldritch-energi och deras rattar och kontroller rör sig av egen vilja.

På uppdrag av Acererak byggde trollkarlen Tuerny dessa kontroller för balors fängelse i område 6. En lyckad DC 12 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana} eller {@skill Investigation})-kontroll identifierar ett antal silvertrådar som leder från dessa kontroller in i område 6 och är fästade vid den fängslade balor.

Den som försöker störa kontrollerna eller ledningarna måste lyckas med ett räddningskast DC 13 eller ta 11 ({@dice 2d10}) kraftskador. Kontrollerna och ledningarna är självreparerande och kan inte avskiljas eller förstöras. Om ceremonin störs kan dock kontrollerna här ställas in för att befria balor.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Om en mekanisk guide spenderar 1 laddning i det här området drar mer energi från Balor, vilket gör att han faller {@condition unconscious} i område 6.

entries.name: Who's Who
entries: Trollkarlen Tuerny var skaparen av den sedan länge försvunna artefakt som kallas {@i Iron Flask of Tuerny the Merciless}, som används för att fånga demoner, djävlar och andra varelser. Denna artefakt blev senare modell för den mindre men fortfarande legendariska magin i järnflaskan. Enligt traditionen blev Tuerny en nalfeshnee-demon innan han försvann ur historien.

entries.name: 6. Captive Balor

entries: I slutet av denna hall pågår någon slags hemsk bindande process. En balor hålls mot väggen, tryckt in mot stenläggningen som föreställer ett stort grönt djävulsansikte. En svart sfär håller demonen på plats och verkar sakta dränera bort dess essens.

Balor {@creature Tarnhem|IMR} är bunden här av Acereraks magi, som har tillverkat en anordning av en {@item sphere of annihilation} som långsamt dränerar bort {@creature Tarnhem|IMR}'s essens för att ge bränsle till gravens magiska funktioner.

En lyckad DC 12 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) kontroll identifierar ett antal silvertrådar som är fästade på Balor och som går till kontrollrummet ({@area area 5|06e|x}). Den som försöker störa kontrollerna eller trådarna måste lyckas med ett DC 13 Konstitutionssparande kast eller ta 11 ({@dice 2d10}) kraftskador. Kontrollerna och ledningarna är självreparerande och kan inte avskiljas eller förstöras.

entries.name: Bargaining with Tarnhem
entries: Om karaktärerna är fria att tala med {@creature Tarnhem|IMR} ber balor dem att avbryta ceremonin i kapellet ({@area area 14|093|x}) och sedan ställa in kontrollerna i {@area area 5|06e|x} för att släppa honom. För att övertyga dem att göra det lovar djävulen allt som står i hans makt. Som ett bevis på god tro kan han berätta hur man på ett säkert sätt öppnar skattkistorna i {@area area 13|08f|x}, och hur hans vapen har tagits till kapellet ({@area area 14|093|x}) och arbetats in i altaret där.
{@creature Tarnhem|IMR} använder {@creature balor} stat-blocket med följande ändringar:

items: När den hålls är {@creature Tarnhem|IMR} {@condition incapacitated} men kan fortfarande tala.

Tills han får tillbaka sina vapen från kapellet ersätts hans långsvärd och piska med följande handlingsalternativ: {@i {@b Fist of Retribution}.} {@i Melee Weapon Attack}: +14 att träffa, räckvidd 3 meter, ett mål. {@i Hit}: 13 ({@dice 2d4 + 8}) smällande skada plus 7 ({@dice 2d6}) brandskada.

entries: Om han släpps, håller {@creature Tarnhem|IMR} alla avtal som han har ingått om att inte skada karaktärerna. Han fokuserar istället sin vrede på {@creature Moghadam|IMR} och Phenex och jagar båda innan han försvinner in i sprickan till de lägre planen i {@area area 16|09e|x}.

Om balor släpps loss blir klotet som binder honom en {@item sphere of annihilation} och lossas. Den reser slumpmässigt runt i graven, men begränsas av gravens magi att stanna inom dess rum och korridorer snarare än att borra sig igenom väggarna. Denna sfär kan styras som vanligt medan den befinner sig i graven, men den kan inte lämna den.

Om {@creature Tarnhem|IMR} inte frigörs, dräneras baloren så småningom bort och blir en del av ett hemskt monument. Hans livskraft driver den svarta sfären i munnen på det stora gröna djävulsansiktet i det här området när Tomb of Horrors är färdigställd.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Om en mekanisk guide spenderar 1 laddning i det här området återgår han {@creature Tarnhem|IMR} till en tidigare period innan så mycket av hans livskraft dränerades och vaknar upp om han är {@condition unconscious}.

entries.name: 7. Forsaken Prison
entries: En smal krypgrund leder hit från den sydligaste gropen i entrén ({@area area 3|065|x}). I botten av ett tre meter långt fall i slutet av krypgrunden finns en eländig cell med en ensam fånge. Hantverkaren Nolzur (en neutral manlig människa {@creature master thief|vgm}, men han är reducerad till 1 träffpunkt) har tillfångatagits och hålls här, hans alkemiska blod dräneras kontinuerligt för att skapa de magiska pigment som används för att måla gravens väggmålningar. Muralisterna dränerar honom med verktyg som tillverkats av stirrars näbbar och håller honom knappt vid liv med helande magi.

Nolzur är för svag för att fly på egen hand, men om han räddas och får läkning och näring hjälper han gärna karaktärerna på alla sätt. Detta inkluderar att berätta för karaktärerna om den allmänna utformningen av Molochs tempel och avslöja {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s sårbarhet för magiska drycker och salvor som återställer träffpunkter (se "{@area Who Dwells Here?|0b4|x}" i {@adventure chapter 4|IMR|4}).

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Om en mekanisk guide spenderar 1 laddning i det här området kommer en av muralisterna hit för att samla in mer blod, för användning i antingen {@area area 3|065|x} eller 10. Att spendera 2 laddningar återställer också ett mått av hälsa till Nolzur, motsvarande effekten av en {@spell cure wounds} besvärjelse.

entries.name: 8. Sculptors' Workroom
entries: Denna arbetsplats används av ett antal neutrala mänskliga skulptörer som skapar föremål för användning i graven. Fem är närvarande när karaktärerna först kommer in i området, övervakade och assisterade av en {@creature girallon|VGM}. Skulptörerna (använd {@creature cultist} stat-blocket) reste hit från Molochs tempel med falskt löfte om en fantastisk betalning för att hjälpa till att bygga graven. De har sedan dess funnit sig oförmögna att lämna platsen.

Skulptörerna söker hjälp för att fly från graven och ger den information de vet i utbyte mot hjälp. De kan berätta hur resten av skulptörerna (i {@area area 10|081|x}) planerar en flyktväg med hjälp av en uppsättning överlägsna {@item mason's tools|PHB} gömda där, och att dessa verktyg också kan försvaga eidolonet i Molochs tempel (se {@area area 25|13a|x} i {@adventure chapter 4|IMR|4}). De vet också att muralisterna är lojala mot {@creature Moghadam|IMR} och inte kan lita på dem.
Den rytmiska sången som magiskt förts in i {@area area 3|065|x} blir högre i detta område.

entries.name: Nolzur's Gift
entries: Om karaktärerna hjälper honom att fly från skräckens grav skickar Nolzur dem senare en uppsättning av sina {@item Nolzur's marvelous pigments}, som magiskt anländer var och närhelst de hamnar efter att äventyret är avslutat. Leveransen innehåller också en liten, omålad miniatyrfigur som föreställer varje karaktär. Varje figur är en liten urverksapparat. Om figurerna målas och hålls till hands animeras de i hemlighet för att hjälpa karaktärerna med små uppgifter när de sover.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Under befäl av Phenex ({@area area 14|093|x}) har {@creature girallon|VGM} fått order om att lyda skulptörerna när de arbetar, men att inte låta dem lämna graven. Varelsen bär facklor i två händer för att ge skulptörerna ljus. Med de andra två händerna delar den ut hammare, mejslar och andra verktyg efter behov.

Girallon utmanar karaktärerna om de inte har ett av {@creature Moghadam|IMR}:s magiska pass. I strid använder den de redskap den håller i som vapen. Använd statistiken för girallons kloattack, men en hammarattack ger slagskada och en mejselattack ger stickskada. En facklanattack ger slående skada plus 2 ({@dice 1d4}) brandskador.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Girallon bär ett gyllene armband (värt 250 gp) på en av sina vänstra armar, med {@creature Moghadam|IMR} magiska symboler som placerar varelsen under effekten av en permanent {@spell dominate monster} förtrollning. Phenex ({@area area 14|093|x}) känner till de kommandoradord som tvingar girallon i tjänst.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Om en mekanisk guide spenderar 1 laddning i det här området, kommer girallonerna att lämna området. Slå en {@dice d4}. Vid 1-2 checkar girallon in hos {@creature Moghadam|IMR} i {@area area 1|05e|x}. På 3-4 går den till Phenex i {@area area 14|093|x}.

entries.name: 9. Artisans' Chambers
entries: Denna sammanhängande serie rum används för närvarande som små lägenheter och förråd för de muralister och skulptörer som arbetar i graven. Rummen är små, glesa och minimalt möblerade.
Den rytmiska sången som magiskt förts in i {@area area 3|065|x} blir högre i detta område.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Dessa områden innehåller endast personliga tillhörigheter, inklusive flera inbjudningar från {@creature Moghadam|IMR} om anställning vid graven och med överdrivna löner. Dessutom har en av hantverkarna en karta som visar landvägen från Molochs tempel till Skräckens grav.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Om en mekanisk guide spenderar 1 laddning i det här området får {@dice 1d4 + 1} hantverkare att antingen återvända hit från sitt arbete, eller åka till sitt arbete.

Detta område håller på att byggas om till en andra stor sal. Precis som entréhallen är det en hektisk och högljudd arbetsplats. Ett antal hantverkare putsar väggarna och målar dem med ljusa, färgglada väggmålningar som inkluderar stora sfärer i olika färger. Andra hantverkare arbetar med stenhuggning. Över dem alla vakar en massiv fyrarmad girallon som hjälper till att lysa upp området genom att hålla facklor i var sin hand.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Fem neutrala mänskliga skulptörer (använd {@creature cultist} stat-blocket) som ursprungligen kom från Molochs tempel är här och skapar stenarbeten till graven. De är desperata att fly och arbetar på en hemlig plan.

Åtta neutrala djuptalande muralmålare putsar och målar och täcker golvet med inlagda kakelplattor. De använder samma statistik och svarar på frågor på samma sätt som muralisterna i {@area area 3|065|x}.

{@creature girallon|VGM} har order om att lyda arbetarna men inte låta dem lämna graven. Den utmanar karaktärerna om de inte bär ett av {@creature Moghadam|IMR}:s magiska pass och använder facklorna som vapen. Använd statistiken för girallonens kloattack, men en fackelattack ger slagskada plus 2 ({@dice 1d4}) brandskador.

entries.name: Murals
entries: Om väggmålningarna undersöks, läs följande (från originalet {@adventure Tomb of Horrors|TftYP}):
Väggarna är målade med djurfigurer, märkliga tecken och glyfer och humanoider som poserar med sfärer i olika färger.

entries.name: Golden Sphere
entries: Endast en av sfärerna har särskild betydelse: en gyllene sfär i det nordvästra hörnet som täcker ingången till område 11. Ingången kan märkas bakom klotet, vars magi ännu inte helt döljer den. Den magin hindrar dock alla som bär på guld eller bär kläder som är guldfärgade från att passera genom sfären.

entries.name: Open Passageway
entries: En del av den östra väggen har ännu inte putsats eller målats över och avslöjar passagen till kapellet ({@area area 14|093|x}). Den rytmiska sången som magiskt förts in i {@area area 3|065|x} blir ännu högre vid ingången till gången. En lyckad DC 14 Wisdom ({@skill Perception})-kontroll identifierar sången som tillhörande någon slags ritual som involverar förtrollningsmagi.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Girallon bär ett gyllene armband (värt 250 gp) på en av sina vänstra armar, med {@creature Moghadam|IMR} magiska symboler som placerar varelsen under effekten av en permanent {@spell dominate monster} förtrollning. Phenex ({@area area 14|093|x}) känner till de kommandoradord som tvingar girallon i tjänst.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Om en mekanisk guide spenderar 1 laddning i det här området, kommer girallonerna att lämna området. Slå en {@dice d4}. Vid 1-2 checkar girallon in hos {@creature Moghadam|IMR} i {@area area 1|05e|x}. På 3-4 går den till Phenex i {@area area 14|093|x}.

entries.name: 11. Escape Room
entries: The sculptors have utilized this side chamber to plan their escape, though none of them are present when the characters first come here.

The room is occupied by a life-sized sculpture of a winged girallon. Once it is finished, the sculptors plan to animate the statue using the information from half a {@item manual of stone golems} in their possession. The manual was torn in half and taken from the Temple of Moloch, where the other half still resides. If brought to life, the statue uses the {@creature stone golem} stat block, and the sculptors use it to attack the tomb's girallon guards and flee.
If the characters earn the trust of the sculptors, the sculptors estimate completing the statue will take three days. They ask the characters to help buy them this time.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The partial {@item manual of stone golems} is hidden beneath a pile of rocks in the corner of the room, and can be found with any search of the area. Even incomplete, it is worth 500 gp.
Additionally, the sculptors store a set of superior {@item mason's tools|PHB} here. These tools grant advantage when used to make an appropriate crafting check, and are worth 500 gp.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area either brings the statue one day of work closer or further from completion (a {@chance 50|50 percent} chance for either).

entries.name: 12. False Doors
entries: To gain time to complete their statue in area 11, the sculptors spend much of their time building, destroying, and rebuilding a number of false doors here in the great hall. Two such doors are marked at area 12 on the map.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area creates or removes a false door at random.

entries.name: 13. Chamber of Three Chests
entries: This treasury holds resources for the construction of the tomb, including precious metals and gemstones stored here for safekeeping. A number of bones from former prisoners and creatures lie heaped about these materials, acting as magical guardians for three chests—one made of gold, one made of silver, and one made of oak.
The three locked chests can be opened with a successful DC 14 Dexterity check using thieves' tools. However, doing so triggers this area's protective magic.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Opening the gold chest causes the bones in the room to assemble into a {@creature giant skeleton|TftYP}. Opening the silver chest results in the bones becoming a {@creature skeletal juggernaut|GoS}. Opening the oak chest creates a {@creature skeletal swarm|GoS} from the bones. If more than one chest is opened, these monsters each assemble in turn, with the next appearing when the previous threat is destroyed. However, if all three chests are opened simultaneously, the bones remain inanimate.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Panels meant for the tomb's walls are stored here. Each panel is approximately 2 feet wide and 3 feet long, weighs 20 pounds, and is crafted from various materials of differing value:

items: Twenty gleaming copper panels (worth 25 gp each)
Twenty silver panels (50 gp each)
Ten panels of rare woods inlaid with ivory (150 gp each)
Five panels of ivory with gold inlaid (500 gp each)

entries: The three chests hold the following:

items: The gold chest has four {@item Potion of Greater Healing||potions of greater healing}, a {@item potion of flying}, and a {@item potion of poison}.

The silver chest contains {@item Spell Scroll||spell scrolls} of {@spell guards and wards}, {@spell summon lesser demons|XGE} (see {@adventure appendix C|IMR|8}), and {@spell teleportation circle}; and a {@item wand of web}.
The oak chest holds 278 pp, ninety-seven small gems (worth 10 gp each), and a peridot (5,000 gp).

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes any currently active animated skeletal creature to grow weaker or stronger. Roll a {@dice d4}. On a 1–2, the creature halves its hit points. On a 3–4, the creature doubles its hit points.

The chanting heard throughout the tomb originates in this chapel, whose pews are filled with more than two dozen worshipers—and, oddly, with two large chunks of rough black stone. The chapel appears dedicated to Vecna, decorated with artwork and symbols in honor of the god of evil secrets. The worshipers, all humanoid, appear exhausted as they continue their chant. As you watch, one of them collapses—and is suddenly and horrifyingly {@condition petrified} into another chunk of black stone.

At the far end of the chapel, a handsome priest stands behind an altar block that glows an opalescent blue. The priest is missing his left eye and hand, but has a second set of arms grafted to his body. All three of his arms gesture as if directing the worshipers like a conductor. Two girallons flank him, each of them also missing an eye and hand.
The priest smiles and gestures for you to enter the chapel and take a seat. And the chanting fills your mind with a desire to obey...

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The roughly thirty humanoids here (use the {@creature cultist} stat block) include loyal cultists pressed into service, workers being punished, and captured prisoners. None of the worshipers (except Pentival; see below) can take any actions beyond continuing to chant as long as the priest, Phenex, commands them.

entries.name: Pentival
entries: One of the prisoners includes the lawful good half-dragon paladin Pentival. Drawn to the temple by rumors of its bound balor, Pentival and his party were quickly captured. All his friends have succumbed to the magic of the temple and been transformed into black rock, but Pentival has so far held out. Of all the worshipers, he alone can communicate with the characters, quickly explaining who he is and the nature of the ceremony.

If freed, Pentival joins the characters for the remainder of their time at the tomb. He uses the {@creature half-red dragon veteran} stat block, but has the form of a gold dragon. However, he insists on keeping {@creature Tarnhem|IMR} imprisoned, and on attempting to destroy {@creature Moghadam|IMR}.

entries.name: Phenex
entries: An {@creature incubus} cleric of Vecna, Phenex directs the dark ceremony here. As long as he commands the worshipers (using a bonus action each round), they maintain their chant.

In combat, Phenex first orders the girallons to attack. As needed, he then uses his Charm action to force a character or Pentival to defend him. Due to his fanatic devotion, Phenex does not use his Etherealness action to escape a fight, but remains in the chapel to the bitter end.

entries.name: Girallons
entries: The two girallons that protect Phenex have each had a left hand and eye removed. They use the {@creature girallon|VGM} stat block but can make only three claw attacks as part of their multiattack action.

entries.name: Ceremony
entries: As long as the worshipers chant, the ceremony fueling the balor's prison ({@area area 6|072|x}) remains active. They continue to chant while they are physically able and while Phenex commands them. The ceremony fuels Phenex as well, allowing him to maintain it without need for sustenance or sleep.

Anyone entering the chapel while the ceremony is underway must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or fall under an effect equivalent to a {@spell mass suggestion} spell. While a character is under this effect, Phenex can direct them to sit and join the ceremony. Any character who does so takes up the chant, and has their Constitution score reduced by 1 each round on initiative count 0. A character reduced to 0 hit points while under this effect dies and has their body and all possessions transformed into a chunk of black rock (see below). A character under the effect of the ceremony can make another saving throw at the end of each turn, ending the effect with a success.

(This version of the ceremony is more potent than that suffered by the other worshipers, who would otherwise have all turned to black rock by now. Phenex is concentrating his magic in an effort to defeat the characters.)

If Phenex is defeated, any remaining worshipers immediately cease chanting and collapse into exhausted unconsciousness. Once a character is freed from the ceremony and out of combat, their hit point maximum is restored at a rate of 1 hit point per round. Anyone transformed into a black rock unfortunately remains in this condition.

entries.name: Black Rocks
entries: When a worshiper's life energy has been drained by the ceremony, they are transformed into a large black rock, carried out of the tomb, and set on the hillside (where they'll eventually form the image of a grinning skull). A {@spell greater restoration} or {@spell wish} spell can end the {@condition petrified} condition for one victim, restoring them and their gear.

entries.name: Altar
entries: This block of strange material glows with an inner light of opalescent blue, owing to the missing components of the {@i Infernal Machine of Lum the Mad} wired into its workings. There are three such components, each a deep sapphire blue. Removing one component safely requires a successful DC 14 Dexterity check using thieves' tools, jeweler's tools, or tinker's tools.

In addition, {@creature Tarnhem|IMR}'s flaming whip and lightning-imbued longsword have also been worked into the altar. On a failed check to remove a missing component, these weapons cast a {@spell lightning bolt} or a {@spell fireball} at the character making the check (a {@chance 50|50 percent} chance for either spell; save DC 16 for both). If {@creature Tarnhem|IMR} is freed, he comes here directly to recover these weapons, and is the only creature that can do so. Anyone else attempting to claim them automatically triggers a {@spell lightning bolt} or a {@spell fireball}.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area reverts one of the black rocks back to a living worshiper.

entries.name: 15. Secret Door
entries: A secret door here leads to a hallway beyond. The door is unlocked and can be found with a successful DC 18 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

entries.name: 16. Rift to the Lower Planes
entries: The ceremony that summoned {@creature Tarnhem|IMR} resulted in an unstable rift to the Lower Planes opening up in this area. The far end of the hallway is scribed with glyphs and sigils, and leads to an open fiery pit—a portal to the Abyss. The unstable magic of the portal prevents any creature that is not a fiend from stepping through it. If {@creature Tarnhem|IMR} is freed, he eventually comes this way and escapes.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes a ripple in the rift's magic, allowing a creature to pass through it into the tomb. Roll a {@dice d6}. On a 1–5, treat this effect as a {@spell summon lesser demons|XGE} spell. On a 5–6, treat it as a {@spell summon greater demon|XGE} spell. (See {@adventure appendix C|IMR|8} for both those spells.) Pick one character at random to be treated as the summoner.

entries.name: 17. Flooding Pit
entries: The corridor beyond the secret door at {@area area 15|09d|x} contains three open 10-foot-deep pits. Lying at the bottom of each pit, a number of skeletons are shackled to the walls. In addition, the outline of a door on the south wall of each pit can be seen.

entries.name: Flooding Trap
entries: The first two pits are trapped, such that anyone trying the false door at the bottom causes a stone slab to slide across the opening, the skeletons to animate (see below), and the pit to begin filling with water. It takes 5 rounds to completely fill a pit, leaving no air space at the top. After one hour, the slab opens and the water drains away.

A successful DC 20 Strength check allows a character inside or outside the pit to pry the slab open, allowing escape from the pit. A character proficient with mason's tools can also make a DC 18 Dexterity check using those tools, cracking open the slab on a success.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The first pit contains four humanoid {@creature Skeleton||skeletons}. The second contains two umber hulk exoskeletons (use the {@creature minotaur skeleton} stat block, but treat its greataxe attack as a claws attack and its gore attack as a mandibles attack). The third looks like it contains the skeleton of a large wolf-headed humanoid, but a successful DC 13 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check reveals that the creature is a mix of humanoid and animal bones. The bones do not animate.

When either of the first two pits are sealed, the skeletons within animate. They remain shackled to the walls, but attack any character in the pit to hinder any attempt to escape from the flooding chamber.

entries.name: True Doorway
entries: The third pit contains an actual door leading to area 18.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area opens one closed pit at random, or closes one pit at random if all the pits are open.

entries.name: 18. Guardian Door

entries: A mithral door in the stone wall resembles the figure of a flattened tortle, its arms and legs extended to the four corners, and its shell carved with a complete map of the tomb. Its head is turned in profile, its eye set with a gleaming gem.
When any character approaches the door, the tortle's head animates and intones: "Are you the master?"

entries.name: Opening Riddle
entries: The door unlocks automatically for {@creature Moghadam|IMR} or {@creature Seodra|IMR} the gemsmith. To anyone else, it repeatedly asks, "Who is the master?" The correct answer to the question can be found in {@creature Moghadam|IMR}'s office ({@area area 1|05e|x}): "The true master of the tomb is he who plans its construction." With any answer other than that phrase or the name "{@creature Moghadam|IMR}," the door replies that the speaker is not the master and refuses to open.

entries.name: Soul Gem
entries: The door's eye is gem set with a smaller version of one of a demilich's soul gems. The gem can be removed only by a character proficient with jeweler's tools who succeeds on a DC 13 Dexterity check using the superior jeweler's tools found in {@area area 31|151|x} of {@adventure chapter 4|IMR|4}. A successful check removes the soul gem, which destroys the gem and unlocks the door.
A character who attempts to remove or destroy the gem in any other way must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or take 11 ({@dice 2d10}) force damage.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes the door to intone: "The master does not resort to feeble manipulations of a clock to open this door. You are not the master."

entries.name: 18a. Gemsmith's Workshop
entries: {@creature Seodra|IMR}, a master gemsmith in the employ of {@creature Moghadam|IMR}, maintains her workshop here, although she is currently a prisoner in the Temple of Moloch (see {@adventure chapter 4|IMR|4}).
Beyond the door, a series of overlapping curtains embroidered with a pattern of silvery spiderwebs drape across a stairway leading down.

entries.name: Curtains
entries: The first three curtains are sheets of thick webbing that function as the product of the {@spell web} spell. The fourth is a disguised {@creature trapper|VGM} kept by {@creature Seodra|IMR} as a pet, and which attacks anyone who passes by it except {@creature Seodra|IMR} and {@creature Moghadam|IMR}.
Once the characters move beyond the curtains, read:

This workshop features a number of tables covered in {@item jeweler's tools|PHB} and materials—including three large diamonds. Set against the back wall is a couch upholstered in golden cloth, on which rests a headless body outfitted in elaborate robes.
When the first character descends the stairs, the body rises to its feet.

entries.name: Creature
entries: The body is a {@creature greater zombie|TftYP}, used by {@creature Seodra|IMR} as a manikin and animated assistant. It automatically stands up whenever anyone enters the workshop, but does not attack unless {@creature Seodra|IMR}'s gems are touched (see below).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: In addition to a set of {@item jeweler's tools|PHB}, one worktable contains plans for crafting the jeweled silver skull of a demilich. The three large diamonds (worth 1,000 gp each) have already been cut and fashioned into teeth. These are meant for the skull currently in {@creature Seodra|IMR}'s possession (see {@adventure chapter 4|IMR|4}).

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes the manikin to approach the table and indefinitely pantomime searching for its missing head. Spending 2 charges causes it to search briefly, then settle back down to the couch, where it remains inert until anyone new enters the workshop.

entries.name: Completing the Skull
entries: If {@creature Seodra|IMR} has all six diamond teeth (the three in the Tomb of Horrors, along with the three she has with her in {@area area 31|151|x} of chapter 4), the jeweled eyes from the great statue in the Temple of Moloch ({@area area 25|13a|x} of {@adventure chapter 4|IMR|4}), and the silver skull (also in {@area area 31|151|x} of chapter 4), she will have all she needs to complete Acererak's demilich skull.

The magic of the ritual that creates the skull shrinks down the great rubies of Moloch's eyes to fit the silver skull. The last stage of the ritual involves placing the finished skull atop the manikin in area 18a. The spirit of the archmage Acererak then possesses the manikin and transforms it into an eye of fear and flame. If the characters are present, they can treat with Acererak in this form.

The {@creature eye of fear and flame|MFF} attacks at once if the characters are known to have undertaken any actions against {@creature Moghadam|IMR}, the tomb, or its workers. If not, and if Acererak is impressed with their adventuring acumen, the archmage promises to grant a great boon in exchange for some measure of service necessary for the completion of his tomb. The details of the service are left to your determination. The boon can be the equivalent of a {@spell wish} spell, though whether or not Acererak fulfills any promise is left to you to decide.

data.name: Chapter 4: Temple of Moloch
entries: The Temple of Moloch is an ancient site steeped in magic, and the former home of a legendary artificer. {@creature Thessalar|IMR} was a master alchemist and creator of monsters, whose own blood was said to possess dire magical properties. The artificer's mad plots, thirst for power, and pursuit of lichdom eventually left the temple a ruin long ago. But the characters now find themselves back in that long ago, facing off against the artificer and his host of monstrous guardians in pursuit of the missing components of the {@i Infernal Machine of Lum the Mad}. Having come back in time, the characters have a unique opportunity to explore a site now lost to memory—and to lay claim to its legendary riches.

entries.name: Background
entries: The Temple of Moloch was said to have begun as a series of caverns where the elemental princes Olhydra and Ogrémoch once battled, and in so doing, opened a rift to their respective Elemental Planes. This rift between the Plane of Water and the Plane of Earth resulted in a stream flowing through the caverns, which carries with it gemstones of extreme size and quality—particularly rubies. When ancient peoples came upon these gems, their greed led them to gather as many as possible, and to build a temple at the site to honor Moloch. They built an ornate statue to the exiled archdevil, and set two of the largest ruby gemstones for its eyes.

Centuries later, one of the high priests of the temple, an artificer named {@creature Thessalar|IMR}, was so seduced by power and authority that he slew most of his fellow cultists in a bloody ceremony, then took control of the temple for himself. {@creature Thessalar|IMR} repurposed the chambers of the temple for his own experiments, creating numerous monsters that bore his name (including the thessalhydra), as well as unnatural beasts such as the owlbear that would one day spread across the world.

Several of the missing components of the {@i Infernal Machine of Lum the Mad} made their way to the temple through the years. At the time the characters visit, {@creature Thessalar|IMR} has installed these components in his lab equipment, channeling their magic for the purpose of endless mutation.

Over the years that were the height of {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s power in the temple, the artificer's chief rival was the artificer {@creature Moghadam|IMR}, architect of the Tomb of Horrors. {@creature Moghadam|IMR} recently lured away several sculptors from {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s temple to help construct his tomb, with false promises of vast salaries. To add insult to injury, {@creature Moghadam|IMR} then sent back a party of mercenary thieves and a master gemsmith to steal the temple's most famous gems—the eyes of the great statue of Moloch that is the centerpiece of the site. These thieves came under the pretense of delivering animal subjects for {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s experiments, but were captured. The gemsmith {@creature Seodra|IMR} is now forced to labor for {@creature Thessalar|IMR}, while the thieves are the subjects of dark experiments. All are desperate to escape.

entries.name: Who Dwells Here?
entries: As with the Tomb of Horrors, this version of the temple takes place in a period of the distant past, and incorporates rare elements of D&D lore. You are, of course, free to use or not use such elements—{@creature Thessalar|IMR}, the creation of the owlbear, and so forth—as you see fit. You can easily substitute {@creature Thessalar|IMR} or any other NPCs in the adventure with characters specific to your campaign, or with general NPCs who can fill the same roles.

Several of the temple's residents (including {@creature Thessalar|IMR}, his thessalkraken, and the eidolon) are a much more potent threat than characters of the lower levels suggested for the adventure can safely deal with. The players should be forewarned that their characters should treat with such legendary figures carefully—a warning that is repeated by whichever agent the characters are dealing with.

entries.name: Andras and Stolos
entries: One of {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s most loyal assistants, Andrastolos was the subject of many of the artificer's early magical trials. In a grand experiment, Andrastolos's body and mind were split across two separate beings: {@creature Andras|IMR} and {@creature Stolos|IMR}. Although they both operate in the temple, their split nature and the memory of who they once were disturbs {@creature Andras|IMR} and {@creature Stolos|IMR} so much that they seek each other's ruin. The only thing that keeps both from killing the other is a desperate belief that their original natures might somehow be restored.

entries.name: Andras
entries: {@creature Andras|IMR} is a neutral evil male human assassin with the head of a giant snowy owl. Though he retains his full intellect, his speech is hindered, resembling the hoots and clicks of an owl. Cruel and sadistic, {@creature Andras|IMR} has been installed as the temple's torturer. When the characters arrive, he is overseeing the interrogation of {@creature Moghadam|IMR}'s thieves and their wererat leader, Mack Francache. See {@area area 9|0eb|x} for {@creature Andras|IMR}'s full statistics.

entries.name: Stolos
entries: A reverse of {@creature Andras|IMR}, the neutral {@creature Stolos|IMR} possesses the head of an aging man atop the body of a giant owl. Garrulous and inquisitive, {@creature Stolos|IMR} has been installed as the temple's warden, overseeing the prison and the unfortunate creatures held there. {@creature Stolos|IMR} is a warlock of the Great Old One, but see {@area area 11|0fd|x} for his full statistics.

entries.name: Ard-Sagart
entries: Under {@creature Thessalar|IMR}, the high priests of the temple are chosen from sculptors who craft such perfect statues that the temple's resident eidolon (containing the spirit of the first high priest) selects them for its use. As the temple's current high priest, Ard-Sagart (a lawful evil male human {@creature warlock of the fiend|VGM}) believes that the wayward sculptors who left for the Tomb of Horrors have caused the temple to lose favor with Moloch. He is eager to rectify this situation by recovering as many gemstones as possible from the temple's waters as tribute.

entries.name: Barbatos
entries: The ranger {@creature Barbatos|IMR} (a neutral evil male human; see {@adventure appendix B|IMR|7} for his stat block) uses his tracking, stealth, and combat prowess to trap creatures for selfish gain. He has long worked for {@creature Thessalar|IMR}, trapping animals and monsters to be used in the temple's experiments. As part of his wages, {@creature Barbatos|IMR} has undergone his own experimentation, with {@creature Thessalar|IMR} wiring items made from living creatures directly into the ranger's body.
{@creature Barbatos|IMR} is always accompanied by his animal companion, a {@creature hell hound} named Sadie III.

entries.name: Mack Francache
entries: This neutral {@creature wererat} thief is the leader of the band sent to the temple by {@creature Moghadam|IMR}, and charged with stealing the ruby eyes from the temple's great statue of Moloch. Having failed in his assignment, Francache now languishes in the temple's torture chamber.

entries.name: Seodra
entries: A lawful neutral female genasi from the Quasi-elemental Plane of Mineral, {@creature Seodra|IMR} is a gemsmith who studied under Xagy, the mysterious figure who crafted such masterpiece artifacts as {@i Queen Ehlissa's Marvelous Nightingale}. {@creature Seodra|IMR} accompanied Mack Francache and his thieves to the temple, as her expertise was needed to steal the gem eyes of the great statue of Moloch without damaging them. With the gems in hand, {@creature Seodra|IMR} would have been able to craft the jeweled skull of a demilich for Acererak. Unfortunately, she was captured along with the rest of the thieves, and is now forced to work for {@creature Thessalar|IMR}—crafting the same jeweled skull for his own use. See {@area area 31|151|x} for her statistics.

entries.name: Thessalar
entries: As an artificer, {@creature Thessalar|IMR} is vainglorious, egotistical, and utterly ruthless in furthering his research. His career began as a priest in the service of Moloch, where he rose through the ranks before eventually taking over the temple as a working laboratory. Most of his experiments have involved the pursuit of new forms of life, resulting in such creatures as the thessalhydra and the owlbear. In recent years, he has also researched the prolonging of life—namely his own. {@creature Thessalar|IMR} hopes that by becoming a lich, his research and experiments can continue indefinitely.

Over time, {@creature Thessalar|IMR} has subjected himself to so many of his own experiments that his blood has taken on alchemical and magical properties. He regularly uses it as the basis for many of the reagents used throughout his labs. As a side effect, although {@creature Thessalar|IMR} is now immune to poison and the {@condition poisoned} condition, any magical liquid or salve that restores hit points acts as a poison against him if applied to a piercing or slashing weapon.

Several of {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s prized sculptors have been lured away from the temple by {@creature Moghadam|IMR}, his rival artificer, with promises of false payment to help construct the Tomb of Horrors. Worse, the sculptors took with them their best tools and half a {@item manual of stone golems}. Both items were part of {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s plans to craft a powerful stone golem and send it against {@creature Moghadam|IMR} and his tomb. More recently, {@creature Moghadam|IMR} ordered a group of thieves to assault the temple and steal the gemstone eyes from its great statue of Moloch. {@creature Thessalar|IMR} captured the thieves and put the gemsmith accompanying them to work, but the temple still remains on alert against intruders.
See {@adventure appendix B|IMR|7} for {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s stat block.

entries.name: Who's Who
entries: Little is known regarding Xagy—except as a partial anagram for 'Gygax,' and for her role in crafting Queen Ehlissa's Marvelous Nightingale, one of the artifacts appearing in the first edition {@i Dungeon Masters Guide}. When operated, this magical-mechanical marvel would shoot eye rays of different colors and effects, and produce songs able to work magical wonders.

entries.name: Missing Components
entries: The missing components of the {@i Infernal Machine} at this location can be found in various laboratory chambers throughout the temple. Removing the components deactivates various controls within these chambers, disrupting experiments and freeing creatures.

The components resemble those found at the clock tower in {@adventure chapter 1|IMR|1}, being gemstone-like buttons made of some unknown material and of various colors. The missing components are disbursed as follows:

items: {@area Area 9|0eb|x}. One component, speckled gold
{@area Area 14|10a|x}. One component, cloudy orange
{@area Area 15|110|x}. Three components, all emerald green
{@area Area 16|119|x}. One component, light purple
{@area Area 22|12d|x}. One component, hazy yellow

entries.name: Mechanical Guide
entries: If the characters' mechanical guide is lost or destroyed while they explore the Temple of Moloch, you can make use of a number of options to keep the characters from remaining stranded in the past. {@creature Thessalar|IMR} can repair or rebuild the guide for a suitable price, as can {@creature Moghadam|IMR} if an overland trek is made to reach him. (The sculptors in the temple possess maps showing the way to the Tomb of Horrors.) Alternatively, replacement parts for the guide might be recovered from the bottom of the underground lake at the end of the adventure—if the characters are able to deal with the thessalkraken!

entries.name: Exploring the Temple
entries: The temple is divided into two main sections. Areas 1 through 23 are the working laboratories where {@creature Thessalar|IMR} resides and operates, along with many lizardfolk guards. Areas 24 through 39 make up the temple section, largely inhabited by priests and others who care for the temple's statues as well as its living demigod, the thessalkraken. That creature dwells in a deep subterranean lake beyond areas 30 and 39.
Numbered locations are keyed to the map on page 29.

entries.name: Temple Approach
entries: From the point at which the characters arrive outside the temple, they find themselves within striking distance of a small, isolated village. The villagers—quiet, nervous folk—can provide lodging, meager supplies to trade, and directions to the temple.
From the village, a two-mile trek along a seldom-used road ends at the edge of a fen.

A general bleakness hangs over this area, with only a few clumps of brush and tamarack sprouting here and there. Through this, a narrow causeway leads out to a low mound, upon which stand the outer walls of what must be the temple.

The upper levels of the temple are abandoned and falling to ruin, as {@creature Thessalar|IMR} focuses his activities in the dungeons below. Once the characters cross the causeway, they easily spot a stone staircase leading down.

entries.name: Never Alone
entries: As the characters explore the Temple of Moloch, keep in mind that this is an active, living dungeon filled with guards, servants, and monsters. Different areas provide information on lizardfolk guards heading out on patrol and monsters potentially breaking free and running amok. When that happens, keep a rough idea of where those guards and monsters might be heading, and let the characters hear or see them as they skulk about. Not every encounter with a wandering monster or patrol needs to end in combat, but knowing that they don't have free run of the dungeon will help keep the characters on their toes.

In addition to those potential encounters, two unusual monsters also patrol the temple complex, and can be encountered at any time, wandering through any corridors or rooms—a thessalhydra and another creation of {@creature Moghadam|IMR}'s known as the thessalheart construct.

entries.name: Thessalhydra
entries: When the characters first enter the temple, roll a {@dice d4}. On a 1–2, the temple's guardian {@creature thessalhydra|HftT} is patrolling the laboratory section (areas 1 to 23). On a 3–4, it patrols the temple section (areas 24 to 39). There are no fixed mechanics for encounters with the thessalhydra, but feel free to have it show up in the distance whenever the characters need incentive to keep moving. The thessalhydra ignores lizardfolk guards and known servants of {@creature Thessalar|IMR}, but attacks all other creatures on sight. Accustomed to inspiring fear, and having grown somewhat lazy in its guardian role, it is usually content to let foes flee from it rather than pursuing.

Each time the characters finish a long rest in the temple, the thessalhydra leaves its current zone and takes up a patrol in the other zone. The thessalheart construct switches to the opposite zone (see below).

entries.name: Thessalheart Construct
entries: The {@creature thessalheart construct|IMR} is a strange magical-mechanical device that struts about like a chicken, and which features a human heart beating madly behind its glass front. The construct always wanders the zone opposite to the thessalhydra's zone, and for good reason.

The human heart that sits within the construct is magically connected to the thessalhydra, tapping into the power of the {@i Infernal Machine} components as it roams, and feeding that power to the monster as restorative energy. Whenever the thessalhydra is taken to 0 hit points, it stays dead for 1 hour before returning to life with full hit points. Destroying the construct or claiming all the {@i Infernal Machine} components is the only way to end this effect.

The thessalheart construct has a telepathic bond to {@creature Thessalar|IMR}, who becomes aware of the characters through the construct's senses if they encounter it as they wander. If encountered, the construct gets close enough to identify the characters, then attempts to flee to protect itself.

Stairs from the surface lead down to this damp vaulted chamber. The floor is strewn with bones and rubble. The ceiling is supported by arches meeting at the twenty-foot-high domed peak, and is obscured by thick webs. Corridors lead off to the east, south, and west, with the west ending at a heavy oak door with bronze fittings.

entries.name: Arrow Slit
entries: Any character who succeeds on a DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check notices an arrow slit concealed in a gap in the stairwell stones. The guards in {@area area 5|0db|x} watch the stairs through this slit, giving them a warning of the characters' approach.

entries.name: Oak Door
entries: Anyone who listens at the door to the west and succeeds on a DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check hears a moaning that rises and fades away (caused by strong breezes in {@area area 2|0cd|x}). Opening the door causes the breeze to fill this corridor, creating the effect of a {@spell gust of wind} spell.

entries.name: Creature
entries: The webs on the ceiling conceal a mutated giant spider with the beak of a giant owl (use the {@creature grell} stat block). This creature escaped from {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s labs and has been allowed to lair here to watch over the entrance. The lizardfolk have nicknamed it "Thacko."

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A character who searches the chamber and succeeds on a DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check finds 19 sp and a small ruby (worth 20 gp) inside a lizardfolk skull.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes the guards in {@area area 5|0db|x} to change shifts, allowing the characters to pass through here without being noticed. Spending 2 charges also causes Thacko to grow younger or older. Roll a {@dice d4}. On a 1–2, the creature halves its hit points. On a 3–4, the creature doubles its hit points.

entries.name: 2. Water Room
entries: This natural cavern provides fresh water for the temple from the cold and fast-flowing stream along its western edge. The stream enters from the north along a tunnel, and exits to the south in the same manner. A cold wind blows from the south tunnel, generated above the subterranean lake the stream flows into (accessed via {@area area 30|14f|x} or area 39).
Numerous barrels, casks, and buckets are stored here, all used to collect fresh water.

entries.name: Pool
entries: The stream forms a small pool 7 feet deep at its center, which is home to numerous small, white blindfish and crayfish. An unusual mineral formation occupies the bottom of the pool. With a successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check, a character identifies the formation as a limed-over skeleton.

entries.name: Tunnels
entries: The tunnel to the north has no air space within it, and leads back to the underground spring that is the stream's source. The tunnel to the south is higher, leaving an ample air space along which the brisk wind is channeled. Characters can make an arduous journey along the south tunnel to the underground lake (see that section at the end of the adventure), encountering hazards and monsters as you determine.

entries.name: Skeleton
entries: The skeleton is the remains of the temple's first high priest (whose spirit now resides as the eidolon in {@area area 25|13a|x}). If the skeleton is examined by a creature in the water, a successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check reveals a key in its hand. (This fits the secret door leading to the treasure vault in {@area area 38|16b|x}). The key can be easily claimed, but doing so disturbs the skeleton and causes a cylindrical object to dislodge from it. This object is carried off by the stream unless any character in or out of the water succeeds on a DC 18 Dexterity check to snag it.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The watertight ivory tube dislodged by the skeleton contains a vellum map of the temple complex. However, slow seepage has blurred all but a small portion, so that the map now shows only area 1; area 2; the passage to area 3, with that area only a smudge; and the passage to {@area area 26|141|x}, starting about 20 feet south of the secret door in area 3.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 or more charges in this area creates a 10 percent cumulative chance for a ruby (worth {@dice 1d10 × 10} gp) to wash into view from upstream, as well as a 25 percent cumulative chance for {@dice 1d4} {@creature lizardfolk} to arrive on assignment to bring more water into the temple.
Additionally, if 2 or more charges are spent, enough of the lime flakes off the skeleton in the pool that it can be identified without an ability check.

entries.name: 3. Empty Ceremonial Chamber

entries: This chamber resembles a larger version of the entry, with arches meeting at the twenty-five-foot domed peak of the ceiling. A nine-foot-tall wooden platform stands against the south wall, on which several bodies lie wrapped in funeral shrouds.

The wooden platform is used as a dais for religious rites. The faithful are brought here after death, blessed, and then carried to their final resting place in the subterranean lake (where they are consumed by the thessalkraken). The bodies currently upon the platform are four lizardfolk slain during the capture of {@creature Moghadam|IMR}'s thieves, as well as one of those thieves (a female human).

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: Seven small knobs of stone protrude from the south wall at the level of the platform. A character who succeeds on a DC 12 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) or Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check notices which three knobs show the most wear. Pressing those knobs in any order opens the secret door.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area results in four {@creature lizardfolk} guards and a {@creature lizardfolk shaman} opening the secret door to the south and conveying the bodies down the south corridor before vanishing from sight.

entries.name: 4. Guardroom
entries: Since {@creature Moghadam|IMR}'s thieves came to the temple, {@creature Thessalar|IMR} has had the temple on heightened alert and guards stationed around the entrance at all times.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Eight {@creature lizardfolk}, a {@creature lizardfolk shaman}, and the shaman's {@creature two-headed crocodile|IMR} companion rest in this area. If they are alerted to intruders by the lizardfolk in {@area area 5|0db|x}, they head directly for {@area area 1|0c6|x} to challenge them.

entries.name: Secret Tunnel
entries: A secret trapdoor in the floor opens to an access tunnel leading to {@area area 5|0db|x}. It can be found with a successful DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes the guards to change shifts, leaving for the barracks ({@area area 6|0e0|x}). Spending 2 charges reverses time and causes them to instead head into the temple complex to search for {@creature Moghadam|IMR}'s thieves, believing the thieves have just arrived. You determine where the guards might be encountered as a result.

entries.name: 5. Watch Room
entries: The guards here are companions of the force resting in area 4. They are on active duty, watching the stairs down into {@area area 1|0c6|x}.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: If the four {@creature lizardfolk} stationed here spot intruders, two of them travel through the secret tunnel to alert the guards in area 4 and join their hunt. The other two remain here to watch for additional foes descending the stairs, but head out in pursuit of the characters if their allies don't return within a few minutes.

entries.name: Arrow Slit
entries: An arrow slit opens up in a gap in the stairwell stones, and provides a view of any creatures descending the stairs into {@area area 1|0c6|x}.

entries.name: Secret Tunnel
entries: A secret trapdoor in the floor opens to an access tunnel leading to area 4. It can be found with a successful DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes the guards to change shifts, leaving here for the barracks ({@area area 6|0e0|x}). Spending 2 charges causes them to instead head into the temple complex to search for {@creature Moghadam|IMR}'s thieves, believing the thieves have just arrived. You determine where the guards might be encountered as a result.

entries.name: 6. Barracks
entries: This cluttered chamber serves as a barracks for {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s lizardfolk servants. Crude sleeping pallets line the walls, and the place has a foul smell.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Eight {@creature lizardfolk} are off duty here, sleeping or leisurely playing at a rudimentary board game using dice and small stones as playing pieces. If they have been alerted to trouble by the lizardfolk in areas 4 or 5, they head into the temple to challenge intruders.

entries.name: Prisoner
entries: A gruesome scene plays out along the east wall. One of {@creature Moghadam|IMR}'s thieves hangs from manacles there, dead, torn open, and with his innards hanging out, having been given to the lizardfolk to consume.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A successful DC 14 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check made to search through the lizardfolk's possessions uncovers 25 cp, 55 sp, and 10 gp.

In addition, twelve uncut rubies (worth 50 gp each) are being used as pieces for the board game. A successful DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check reveals that the board resembles a partial map of the temple, showing areas 1 to 22.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes the guards to change shifts, leaving for areas 4 and 5. Spending 2 charges also brings the prisoner back to life. Little Gadai is a lawful neutral human {@creature spy}. He joins the characters if allowed to, seeking to rescue and rejoin the other thieves to complete their original mission. His knowledge of the temple is limited to areas 1 through 6.

entries.name: 7. Storage Area
entries: This is a general storage area for the temple, holding crates, sacks, and barrels filled with typical goods in support of temple operations (foodstuffs, cloth, oil, tools, and so forth).

Characters who search this area thoroughly might make an unusual discovery with a successful DC 14 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check, allowing one check per character. Use the Storage Area Discoveries table to determine what a character discovers, or as inspiration for unusual discoveries of your own.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 or more charges in this area has a 20 percent cumulative chance that {@dice 1d4} {@creature lizardfolk} guards arrive to fetch more supplies for the temple. They attack intruders at once.

entries.caption: Storage Area Discoveries
rows: A pile of moldy sacks is contaminated with toxic mold. The character who discovers them must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour.
A tiny {@creature mimic} is disguised as a sack. The mimic deals half damage with its pseudopod and bite attacks, and has only 1 hit point.

A small box holds one {@item Gauntlets of Ogre Power||gauntlet of ogre power} and one {@item Boots of Striding and Springing||boot of striding and springing}. There is no sign of either item's missing mate unless you want to have it found elsewhere in the adventure.
A live parrot in a wicker cage (captured by {@creature Barbatos|IMR} and stashed here pending use in laboratory experiments). The bird claims their name is 'Hector.'

A small barrel holds a live {@creature boggle|VGM}, bound, gagged, and marinating in their own excreted oil. This is the former partner of the boggle steward in areas 36 and 37, who betrayed and left this boggle here in order to pose as both stewards and reap twice the salary. You decide whether this boggle bolts and flees the dungeon if rescued, or whether they accompany the characters to seek vengeance.
A cookbook written in Goblin sits in a cast iron skillet that can be used as a mace. The skillet is engraved in Goblin with the words: PUT IN FIRE FOR COOKING.

A small book is found, colorfully illustrated and offering a variety of rumors and advice regarding monsters and dungeons, information on various items of specialized adventuring gear, and short pieces of fiction.

An empty sack is an uncommon magic item that spits out a random mundane object once per day. Select these items from the {@book trinkets table|PHB|5|Trinkets} in chapter 5 of the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}, or choose any random nonmagical item.
A long piece of oilcloth wraps up a number of missing levers to an {@item apparatus of Kwalish} (to be found in {@area area 29|14c|x}).
A small sack is revealed to be a {@item bag of beans} containing six beans.

A piece of parchment hidden under a crate appears to be a magic treasure map. If the map is not followed to its end within 30 days, it rewrites itself as an entirely new map and any copies made of it turn blank. There is a {@chance 50|50 percent} chance that the map leads to an actual treasure. If not, it leads to a dangerous monster with no treasure.
A sack holds a common magic item and {@dice 1d4} potions, all of your choice.
A leather case holds an uncommon magic item and {@dice 1d4} scrolls, all of your choice.
A box holds a rare magic item of your choice.

entries.name: 8. Office of the Torturer
entries: Characters approaching this area from the north can see activity through the open doorway to {@area area 9|0eb|x}, but can't make out any details until they advance beyond the corridor leading into {@area area 8|0e7|x}.

This chamber serves as the office and apartment of {@creature Andras|IMR}, the temple's torturer and rival of the warden. It holds a bed, a desk, and mundane gear. The desk contains notes on tortured prisoners and any information they've revealed (including the fact that the recently captured thieves were sent by {@creature Moghadam|IMR}). If he is not at work in {@area area 9|0eb|x}, {@creature Andras|IMR} will be found here.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A successful DC 14 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check made to search the desk uncovers several papers stolen from {@creature Stolos|IMR} (see {@area area 11|0fd|x}), which discuss the split nature of {@creature Andras|IMR} and {@creature Stolos|IMR}.

In addition, a locked strongbox can be found under {@creature Andras|IMR}'s bed. It can be opened with a successful DC 15 Dexterity check using thieves' tools, but contains an easily noticed poison needle trap. A failed check triggers the trap, which deals 1 piercing damage and delivers a dose of {@item Blood of the Lycanthrope|IMR|blood of the lycanthrope poison} (see {@adventure appendix C|IMR|8}). The strongbox can be smashed open with a successful DC 20 Strength check.

The strongbox holds treasure collected from {@creature Andras|IMR}'s recent victims—110 sp, 55 gp, 10 pp, five rubies (worth 100 gp each), and a vial of {@item mummy rot antidote|IMR} (see {@adventure appendix C|IMR|8}).

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes {@creature Andras|IMR} to return here from {@area area 9|0eb|x} and prepare to rest.

entries.name: 9. Torture Chamber
entries: The characters can hear what's happening in this area before they see it. Read the following if any character approaches within 30 feet of the open doorway:
A low groaning rises from this chamber, whose open doorway provides a hint of its source. This is a torture chamber, filled with racks, implements of pain, and other foul devices.
As the characters enter, read the following, making adjustments as necessary if {@creature Andras|IMR} is not here:

Two prisoners and a frantic rat lie strapped to tables, and are being worked on by a humanoid figure with the head of a snowy owl. Silver wires connect the tables to a complex control panel standing between them.

entries.name: Andras
entries: The result of one of {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s grand experiments, {@creature Andras|IMR} has the body of a male human and the head of a massive snowy owl. Like that of any owl, his head can rotate almost fully around for 360-degree vision.

The prisoners are two of {@creature Moghadam|IMR}'s thieves, who {@creature Andras|IMR} is pressing for additional information as to their raid and {@creature Moghadam|IMR}'s plans. However, the torturer is almost impossible to understand, with his speech resembling the hoots and clicks of an owl. Conversing with {@creature Andras|IMR} requires a successful DC 10 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check or a {@spell speak with animals} spell, but the torturer speaks to the characters only in bold threats. In combat, {@creature Andras|IMR} uses weapons coated in {@item Blood of the Lycanthrope|IMR|blood of the lycanthrope poison} (see {@adventure appendix C|IMR|8}). He uses the {@creature assassin} stat block with the following changes:

items: He is neutral evil, and can speak and understand Common and Giant Owl.
{@creature Andras|IMR} has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or sight.

The poison effect on his shortsword and light crossbow attacks is replaced with the following: If the target is a humanoid, it must succeed on a DC 11 Constitution saving throw or be cursed with wererat lycanthropy.

entries: {@creature Andras|IMR} carries keys that open the concealed door leading to {@area area 23|132|x}.

entries.name: Prisoners
entries: Mack Francache, the neutral {@creature wererat} leader of {@creature Moghadam|IMR}'s thieves, is the unwilling subject of one of {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s sadistic experiments, conducted by {@creature Andras|IMR}. His lycanthropic blood is being drained for study by {@creature Thessalar|IMR}, who has already discovered ways in which it might be weaponized (see "{@area Poisons|20f|x}" in {@adventure appendix C|IMR|8}).

The silver wires connect Francache to a lawful neutral female human {@creature bandit captain} named Big Gadai (sister to the dead thief in {@area area 6|0e0|x}) and a normal rat. As {@creature Andras|IMR} operates the controls to this strange torture device, he causes Francache's lycanthropy to transform the rat into a duplicate of Big Gadai, to the pain and horror of everyone involved. When the rat is in human form, it insists that it is the real Big Gadai, as does the real Big Gadai.

Francache bargains with the characters for his freedom, promising anything he can in return—including knowledge of the Tomb of Horrors. (His previous assignment for {@creature Moghadam|IMR} was to spy on its workers while in rat form.)

entries.name: Control Panel
entries: The control panel is covered with dials, switches, and buttons—including a speckled gold button recognizable as one of the missing components of the {@i Infernal Machine}. Removing this component deactivates the controls and releases the restraints on the tables, freeing Francache, Big Gadai, and the rat.

Anyone attempting to disrupt the controls or the wires must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or take 11 ({@dice 2d10}) force damage. The controls and the wires are self-repairing, and cannot be severed or destroyed.

entries.name: Concealed Door
entries: Located at the back of an empty iron maiden, this locked door leads to {@area area 23|132|x}, and is used by {@creature Andras|IMR} to check on the clones there. It can be detected with a successful DC 14 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. Without the key carried by {@creature Andras|IMR}, its lock can be picked with a successful DC 18 Dexterity check using thieves' tools, or it can be forced with a successful DC 18 Strength check.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes {@creature Andras|IMR} to return to his quarters ({@area area 8|0e7|x}) to rest. If {@creature Andras|IMR} and {@creature Stolos|IMR} are both at this location, spending 3 charges results in both transforming back into their original forms—the human Andrastolos and his giant snowy owl companion. If restored to normal, Andrastolos uses {@creature Andras|IMR}'s statistics but his alignment reverts to neutral. He is endlessly grateful to the characters, providing any information about the temple he can (he is familiar with areas 1 through 23), and offering to guide the party as needed.

entries.name: 10. Prison Cells
entries: Characters entering this area can see activity through the open doorway to {@area area 11|0fd|x}, but can't make out any details until they advance. If the characters engage in any noisy or noticeable activity here (including advancing down the corridor with light sources), {@creature Stolos|IMR} emerges from {@area area 11|0fd|x} to investigate.
A long hallway leads past six cell doors, alternating three on each side. Five of the doors are constructed from iron bars, with the exception of what appears to be a glass door at the end.

The doors to the cells are locked, and {@creature Stolos|IMR} (in {@area area 11|0fd|x}) has the keys. They can also be unlocked with a successful DC 16 Dexterity check using thieves' tools, or forced open from outside the cell with a successful DC 20 Strength check.

entries.name: Prisoners
entries: The cells are occupied as follows:

entries.name: 10a
entries: Three {@creature lizardfolk} here are being punished for various transgressions. Mean-tempered and suspicious, they nonetheless offer information regarding the temple in exchange for their freedom, knowing their fate is otherwise horrible experimentation. They are likely to turn against the party at the first opportunity.

entries.name: 10b
entries: Two of {@creature Moghadam|IMR}'s thieves (both lawful evil {@creature Spy||spies}) are incarcerated here, one wounded and one near death, and both desperate to be freed. They are periodically taken out for interrogation in {@area area 9|0eb|x}, and are aware that experiments performed on them have created clones of themselves. They vehemently claim to be the real thieves.

The two join the characters if allowed, seeking to rescue and rejoin the other thieves to complete their original mission. Their evil nature inspires them to betray the characters if doing so works to their advantage.

entries.name: 10c
entries: This cell is currently empty.

entries.name: 10d
entries: This cell contains magically created duplicates of the thieves in 10b. They also claim to be the real thieves. (At your determination, these might be the real thieves, with the duplicates in 10b unaware of their true nature.)

entries.name: 10e
entries: Two {@creature Doppelganger||doppelgangers} are being held here for study and as eventual experimental subjects. They attempt to look like Mack Francache, {@creature Seodra|IMR} the gemsmith, or anyone else they've seen pass through the cell area in order to escape.

entries.name: 10f
entries: This cell is sealed off behind a padlocked sheet of transparent glassteel—a resilient magical material as strong as metal—to prevent the escape of the {@creature adult oblex|MTF} inside. The oblex can still use its Eat Memories action and Sulfurous Impersonation trait to create copies of anyone approaching too closely.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes one of the cell doors (chosen at random, excluding cell F) to rust with age and weaken. In this state, a door can be forced opened with a successful DC 10 Strength check from either side.

entries.name: 11. Office of the Warden
entries: Adjust the following text if the characters attract {@creature Stolos|IMR}'s attention as they approach this area.

The end of the cell hallway opens up to an office. A most unusual figure is seen behind a large desk strewn with papers—a huge white owl with the head of an aging man, seated atop a large, ornate bird stand. The figure reads while turning pages with a talon, muttering curses about, "That damned thumb-screwer, {@creature Andras|IMR}."

entries.name: Stolos
entries: The result of the same experiment that produced {@creature Andras|IMR} ({@area area 9|0eb|x}), {@creature Stolos|IMR} has the head of a male human atop the body of a giant snowy owl. He readily converses with the characters even if their initial appearance is suspicious, asking them friendly questions with the aim of discovering if {@creature Moghadam|IMR} sent them.

If asked about his unusual appearance, {@creature Stolos|IMR} angrily admits that he and {@creature Andras|IMR} derived from a singular human subject and his giant snowy owl companion years before. The two hybrid creatures now have an intense hatred for one another, owing to a mutual disgust for their split nature.

{@creature Stolos|IMR} offers to work with the characters if they harm or impede {@creature Andras|IMR} (most easily by freeing the prisoners being tortured in {@area area 9|0eb|x}). His only real aim is for the characters to sow chaos before the temple's guards invariably deliver them back into his custody.
{@creature Stolos|IMR} uses the {@creature warlock of the Great Old One|VGM} stat block with the following changes:

items: He is neutral evil.
He has a flying speed of 30 feet.
Replace his dagger attack with the following attack: {@b {@i Talons}.} {@i Melee Weapon Attack}: +3 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@i Hit}: 8 ({@dice 2d6 + 1}) slashing damage.

entries: {@creature Stolos|IMR} carries the keys to the cells in {@area area 10|0f3|x}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A successful DC 14 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check to search the desk uncovers a box of nine {@item Paper Bird|WDH|paper birds} (see {@adventure appendix C|IMR|8}) used to send messages to {@creature Thessalar|IMR}.

In addition, a locked strongbox can be found under the desk. It can be opened with a successful DC 15 Dexterity check using thieves' tools, but contains an easily noticed poison gas trap. A failed check triggers the trap, which sprays a dose of {@item Dust of the Mummy|IMR|dust of the mummy poison} (see {@adventure appendix C|IMR|8}) at the character making the check. The strongbox can be smashed open with a successful DC 20 Strength check, but doing so targets each character within 5 feet of the strongbox with {@item Dust of the Mummy|IMR|dust of the mummy poison}.

The strongbox holds the treasure collected from {@creature Stolos|IMR}'s current prisoners—45 gp, 23 pp, ten small rubies (worth 25 gp each), a {@item ring of water walking}, and a vial of {@item blood of the lycanthrope antidote|IMR} (see {@adventure appendix C|IMR|8}).

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes {@creature Stolos|IMR} to leave and check on the cells in {@area area 10|0f3|x}. If {@creature Andras|IMR} and {@creature Stolos|IMR} are both at this location, spending 3 charges results in both transforming back into their original forms. See {@area area 9|0eb|x} for details.

entries.name: 12. Owl Laboratory
entries: Whenever anyone enters this area, a huge cacophony of shrieks and hooting is raised from the animals kept here. The walls of the room are lined with cages filled with {@creature Owl||owls}—one pair each of barn owls, horned owls, screech owls, and snowy owls. Against one wall, a huge cage holds a {@creature giant owl}. In addition, several terrariums hold live mice, lizards, and small snakes used as food for the owls. Various cabinets hold prepared owl food, supplies, and implements for both the care and dissection of these creatures.
Any character who feeds the owls or succeeds on a DC 14 Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check can successfully quiet them.

entries.name: Barbatos
entries: The neutral evil human ranger {@creature Barbatos|IMR} is either here or in area 13 (a {@chance 50|50 percent} chance for either; see {@adventure appendix B|IMR|7} for his stat block), accompanied by his {@creature hell hound} companion, Sadie III. He carries keys to the cages in this area and area 13. Arrogant and cruel, {@creature Barbatos|IMR} threatens and taunts the characters before attempting to capture them for {@creature Thessalar|IMR}.
